Office of Frivate Cooperation
Brings into effect the active participation of private
agencies, business firms, professional groups, educational
and cultural societies, non-profit organizations and individuals
who can help achieve the objectives of the government’s overseas
information program. To date more than 700 projects have been
arranged. These fall into the major categories of: overseas
advertising, inserts in letters sent abroad, collections of
American magazines for distribution overseas, exhibits, letter
writing, town affiliations, community participation programs,
unofficial ambassadors and hospitality projects for foreign
students in the U, 3,
Fee organization Steps
Internal organization of the U. S. Information Agency, is based on
three concepts:
(1) The field is where the information job is performed.
Programs will be developed in each country to fit specific
needs, and the media services in Washington will provide the
field posts with materials suited to each particular country.
(2) There will be a minimum of superstructure in Washington.
In practice, the transfer of the IIA from the Department of State
and the merging into the new Agency of the MSA foreign informa¬
tion activities are steps which are not to be taken overnight
on a "crash" basis. They will be accomplished in a period of
months.
(3) Area supervision with full authority for field operations
has now been established in the offices of the Assistant
Directors.
(4) Reprogramming within the 1954 budgetary limitation will
result in reductions in the number of overseas posts, information
centers, broadcast hours, and other media activities.
History of the Program
Over the years, the U. S. Government has acquired considerable
experience in the broad and complex field of information and public
affairs abroad. Beginning with the cultural program for the other
American Republics, authorized by the Congress in 1939 and undertaken
by the Department of State in 1940, and the several programs of the
Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs initiated shortly thereafter, the
Government began to learn through experience the capacities, limitations
and problems of the information approach. The war situation produced
the Office of War Information which, together with the resources of the
Armed Forces, took us into the complex arena of psychological warfare.
In 1945-4^, on the premise that the emergency was over, the
psychological warfare function disappeared. The remaining functions
were drastically reduced in scope and were grouped within the Department
of State in the Office of International Information and Cultural Affairs
